Thanks, Empyre!

Where I play, merchants typically have a cap of 150K tops, so if an item is worth anything over that, I have no way of knowing how much it's actually worth.

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
In general, there's no way of knowing for a specific environment. The Lore required to identify an item (and the UMD required to use a restricted item) can be altered by editing 2da files, so there's no guarantee that the default values apply to your specific environment. The cost of an item is determined by the base item type (eg. dagger, longsword, small shield) and the item properties on the item, and all of this can be customised too.

For a vanilla environment, you can use the toolset to check item value. That way you can calculate the cost of the most expensive item that you're likely to encounter and set your Lore accordingly. Bear in mind that Identify and Legend Lore also give Lore bonuses which can be useful if they're easily available.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Shame. Alright, with even more faffing, how about creating a character with (for example) 20 Lore, beam them into wherever you're playing and see if they can id what you want, if not, try one with 30 ranks, then 40, and so on until you can id the item(s). That gives you a 10 point Lore window, which you can then narrow further should you wish - maybe try (eg) 35 ranks if you know you need between 30 and 40, and narrow it down progressively, depending on how obsessive you're feeling.

As I say, highly faff-intensive, but hey-ho.

Cheers

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content:
One thing you CAN do is to write down the WoG price of several items of differenty types. Preferably items which also COULD exist in a vanilla environment (like a weapon+1, boots of speed, swordsman's belt, shield 5% protection against electrical, like that) which have an enhancement or a magical property or three, but aren't worth more than 150K.

Then you create a new, empty module with the toolset, create a 2x2 empty area (toolset forces you to create an area), save it as "test" and make sure you have your empty area open. You now can check all standard item blueprints or even create new items. When you "edit" an item or "edit copy", you can see the "value" on which item level restriction as well as Lore and UMD needed are based on.
OR, if you tell me the exact properties of an item, I can check the vanilla value for you. Takes me just minutes, because I know where to look.

By comparing the WoG prices with what you find in the toolset you might be able to derive a pattern, using the vanilla lists.
You would need to know the exact Lore or UMD needed for the items whose value you noted down, of course.

You say WoG isn't high magic, so it is unlikely there will be any item with a value higher than what would be 4.2 million in vanilla (equal to item level 40), it probably is less. 

Of course you could download solo WoG, open it with the toolset and check item blueprints and scripts. You also could check 2da's with a 2da editor.
Just that this... way too much searching. For a module that size and with so many haks it also takes ages to check anything. Toolset might crash or freeze frequently, even on a fast computer.

That, and we don't know what has been changed since solo WoG was published.
